posts.post_content:
Finally, a good commander for a Red and Blue instants and sorceries based deck!  
  
The only other pure Blue and Red generals don't fit that well with a deck focused around instants and sorceries, which seems like RU's specialty. [Nin, the Pain Artist](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Nin, the Pain Artist) feels like a build-around Commander, requiring you to get creatures with Indestructible or high toughness so she can draw you cards turn after turn, or some way of negating any card advantage your opponent's will get if you use her ability on one of their creatures. [Jhoira of the Ghitu](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Jhoira of the Ghitu) obviously works best with extremely expensive or hard to cast cards that you can then cheat into play easily-in other words not counterburn. I shouldn't have to explain why [Tibor and Lumia](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Tibor and Lumia) make for a subpar general. The [Niv-Mizzet](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Niv-Mizzet)s were therefore the best, but the Firemind has much better synergy with powerful combos like himself+[Curiosity](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Curiosity). The Dracogenius ... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

Posted By: Nagoragama (4/23/2013 5:42:17 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content: Melek is doubtlessly THE BEST of the DGM guild champions. Not only Izzet was wanting a spellslinger general since forever ([Tibor and Lumia](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Tibor and Lumia) don't count), he is also miles closer to the power level people want to see then dorks like [Emmara Tandris](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Emmara Tandris). Play him with [Galvanoth](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Galvanoth) (and [Leyline of Anticipation](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Leyline of Anticipation) so you can curve onto him without missing Galv's first trigger). Have fun. Play him with [Mystical Tutor](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mystical Tutor). Win.
posts.html:
Melek is doubtlessly THE BEST of the DGM guild champions. Not only Izzet was wanting a spellslinger general since forever (Tibor and Lumia don't count), he is also miles closer to the power level people want to see then dorks like Emmara Tandris. Play him with Galvanoth (and Leyline of Anticipation so you can curve onto him without missing Galv's first trigger). Have fun. Play him with Mystical Tutor. Win.

posts.post_content:
I enjoy that Melek is really, really good: But I also think that [Mirko Vosk](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mirko Vosk) and [Emmara Tandris](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Emmara Tandris) were appropriate cards to print that are OK as they are now.   
  
People expected WAY too much out of the Maze Runners. These are Not quite even Champions. These aren't, in every single case, the Guildmaster's Favored and Beloved Right Hands. These aren't the Darth Vaders to the Emperors. Their kinda more like Rogue Desperate Last Minute Heroes. Sometimes they're already well-known and established in the Guild, but actually, in the vast majority of cases, they're people who are sort-of borderline in their Guild and the Guild decides: "Here is your chance to be our Hero, plus if you fail we are willing to risk your death."  
  
Massacre Girl is a crazy Zealot of the Guild that Rakdos sort of favors, but everyone is Expendable in Rakdos anyway.   
  
Melek was Invented on the spot for the Maze Running, meaning neither [Niv-Mizzet](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Niv-Mizzet) nor ... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

posts.post_content:
I'm extremely bothered by the rulings that are claiming you are allowed to play Lands off the top of your library. There's absolutely no reason to believe his rules text enables that. It doesn't even enable you to play cards, rather to cast them, and we all know Lands are not cast. This is absurd and must be an error, or else we're beginning an era of Magic in which rules are entirely inconsistent.  
  
Wizards, rectify this. Thank you.
posts.html:
I'm extremely bothered by the rulings that are claiming you are allowed to play Lands off the top of your library. There's absolutely no reason to believe his rules text enables that. It doesn't even enable you to play cards, rather to cast them, and we all know Lands are not cast. This is absurd and must be an error, or else we're beginning an era of Magic in which rules are entirely inconsistent.

Wizards, rectify this. Thank you.

Posted By: bowlofgumbo (5/2/2013 8:54:36 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Awesome ability, amazing art, but very small stats. He doesnt do anything on Turn 6, he also lets your opponents know what card you are drawing. So there is no longer a surprise factor for you. But... you are getting Free spells at the cost of building a spell-oriented deck.   
  
The risks and rewards are there but this isn't a limited card. This is a kitchen table card and should be treated as such.   
  
I doubt this will see much play in standard due to its 2/4 stats. With [Mizzium Mortars](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mizzium Mortars) being in standard I see this guy being easily removed and a waste of 6 mana and a turn for yourself. You often wish that creatures with abilities like Melek are 1/5 instead of 2/4 because they really aren't going to be attacking, they are commanders and generals of your army not fighters. 2/5 rating because of that.
posts.html:

I doubt this will see much play in standard due to its 2/4 stats. With Mizzium Mortars being in standard I see this guy being easily removed and a waste of 6 mana and a turn for yourself. You often wish that creatures with abilities like Melek are 1/5 instead of 2/4 because they really aren't going to be attacking, they are commanders and generals of your army not fighters. 2/5 rating because of that.

posts.post_content:
Melek, meet the [Thrumming Stone](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Thrumming Stone). I'm sure you'll find its magic-resonating properties most interesting.  
  
No, seriously, ripple is the thing you guys've been looking for. I've already planned a deck with him, the stone, a [Nivix Cyclops](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Nivix Cyclops), 4 [Index](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Index), 4 [Reminisce](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Reminisce) and a bunch of other 4-ofs.  
  
Although, if you *really* wanted to go overkill, you could use [Research](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Research) to put more copies of a card into your library, have a [Mirror Gallery](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mirror Gallery) and several copies of both Melek and the Stone and a way to continuously return cards to your library, like [Paradigm Shift](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Paradigm Shift) imprinted on [Isochron Scepter](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Isochron Scepter) with a bunch of [Thought Eater](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Thought Eater)s in play or some other thing.   
And then someone casts a [Mindbreak Trap](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mindbreak Trap) and you kill everything.  
  
Also works with, as has been stated, [Unexpected Results](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Unexpected Results)... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)
